medical: The patient has been suffering from intractable back and leg pain. She is being carefully worked up. Unfortunately, she has 4-level severe lumbar internal disc disruption. Her L1-L2, L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5, and L5-S1 discs all reproduce concordant lumbar back pain when pressurized. Her last procedure was diagnostic and therapeutic on 03/29/10. Medication was placed intradiscally after a diagnostic discogram. The intradiscal steroid has helped her back pain tremendously. Her pain has decreased approximately 70% and she is once again playing golf. She has a new paracentral disc herniation at the L3-L4 level that is frankly compressing the L4 nerve root. This disc herniation and lumbar radiculopathy was addressed during the same trip to the OR. Her leg pain is 100% eradicated at this point in time. Her axial back pain is greatly improved, but not completely eradicated. There is absolutely no surgery at this point in time that would be beneficial for her axial back pain due to her lumbar internal disc disruption. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Significant for anxiety disorder. PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: Foot surgery, abdominal surgery, and knee surgery. CURRENT MEDICATIONS: Lipitor and Lexapro. ALLERGIES: She is allergic to sulfa medications. SOCIAL HISTORY: She is married, retired. Denies tobacco or ethanol use. FAMILY HISTORY: Father died of mesothelioma. Mother gastric problems. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: No recent history of night sweats, fevers, weight loss, visual changes, loss of consciousness, convulsion, or dysphagia. Otherwise, review of systems is unremarkable, and a detailed history can be found in the patient's chart. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Physical exam can be found in great detail in the patient's chart. ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: The patient is suffering from multilevel lumbar internal disc disruption as well as an element of lumbar facet joint syndrome. Her lumbar facet joints were denervated approximately 6 months ago. The denervation procedure helped her axial back pain approximately 40% when standing. With extension and rotation it helped her axial back pain approximately 70%. She is now able to swing a golf club. She was unable to swing a golf club due to the rotational movements before her rhizotomy. She is currently playing golf. Her L4 radicular symptoms have resolved since her therapeutic transforaminal injection. I am going to have her fitted with a low profile back brace and I am starting her on diclofenac 75 mg p.o. b.i.d. We will follow her up in 1 month's time.
layman:
The patient has severe back and leg pain that has been very hard to treat. She has serious damage to four discs in her lower back (L1‑L2, L2‑L3, L3‑4, and L4‑5). Pressing on each of these discs makes her back hurt the same way. The last time she had a procedure (on March 29, 2010) was to diagnose and treat the problem. A steroid was injected directly into the disc after a discogram. That steroid helped her back pain a lot—about 70% better—and she is now playing golf again.

She now has a new herniated disc just off the center at the L3‑L4 level that is pressing on the L4 nerve root. This herniation and the nerve pain were treated during the same surgery. Her leg pain is completely gone. Her back pain has improved a lot but is not gone entirely. Because of the severe disc damage, no surgery would help her back pain right now.

**Past medical history**: anxiety disorder.  
**Past surgeries**: foot, abdominal, and knee operations.  
**Current medications**: Lipitor (for cholesterol) and Lexapro (for anxiety).  
**Allergies**: sulfa drugs.  
**Social**: married, retired, does not smoke or drink.  
**Family**: father died of mesothelioma; mother has stomach problems.  

**Review of systems**: No recent night sweats, fevers, weight loss, vision changes, fainting, seizures, or trouble swallowing. Otherwise, everything is normal; more details are in her chart.

**Physical exam**: Full details are in her chart.

**Assessment and plan**: She has damage to multiple discs and some facet joint problems. Six months ago, her facet joints were treated with a denervation procedure that reduced her back pain by about 40% when standing and by about 70% when she bends or twists. Because of that, she can now swing a golf club, something she couldn’t do before the procedure. The nerve pain from the L4 root is gone after a therapeutic injection. I will give her a low‑profile back brace and start her on diclofenac 75 mg by mouth twice a day. We will check back in one month.
